sentences.sentence: The campaign to cancel Nick CoatsworthThere are as many opinions as there are experts, said Franklin Delano Roosevelt.

And while the COVID-19 pandemic may yet pale in historical comparison to FDR's battle against the Great Depression and World War II, today's crisis has been marked by sharp combat between competing academics.OzSage is a newly established group of public health academics based on the UK's Independent Scientific Advisory Group for Emergencies.

According to its website, OzSage met for the first time on August 16.This timing exculpates OzSage, and its members, of any responsibility for a joint complaint signed by 24 clinical academics in early August to the Australian National University against ANU employee, Associate Professor Nick Coatsworth.Coatsworth, better known for his former role as Australia's deputy chief medical officer, was also the subject of a separate but nearly simultaneous complaint signed by, you guessed it, 24 clinical academics and sent to the Royal Australasian College of Physicians.The trigger for the complaints, it seems, was first a May 15 op-ed the handsome doctor wrote for The Sydney Morning Herald discussing his first-hand experience of ensuring effective health advice was disseminated through the media along with his distaste for experts who talked down the safe and effective AstraZeneca vaccine.These gruesome thought crimes were repeated by Coatsworth in another op-ed for our sister publication on July 23.You might think he was onto something here, given the significant rump of Australians too hesitant to take the freely available AstraZeneca due to scaremongering about ultra-rare side effects, which studies continue to show are basically on-par with the risks inherent in the Pfizer jab (whose protections astoundingly wear off quicker than AstraZeneca).ANU's Dean of the College Health and Medicine, Russell Gruen, believed Coatsworth's commentary, should it be perceived as discourteous by other experts, could have potentially breached ANU's code of conduct.

No word on whether RACP president John Wilson believed Coatsworth breached his organisation's code of conduct, but the group said the matter does not involve the college.When prodded, the ANU confirmed the complaint did not have "anything to do with OzSage" and the matter was closed.Which is lucky, as both Gruen and ANU vice-chancellor Brian Schmidt have since become members of OzSage in a decision we are told was "motivated by a commitment to helping better connect leaders with a broad range of COVID-19 experts and high-quality research in the pursuit of transparent decision-making".
"All concerned continue to exercise their right to free speech.

We hope they will exercise this right in a respectful way in line with Australian values," the ANU said.When asked what he thought of the matter, Education Minister Alan Tudge said the "contest of ideas will be, and by necessity must be, robust".
"Perhaps he hurt some feelings because he used forthright language.
Well, grab a Kleenex, but that is not sufficient reason to shut someone down.

"While we may never know who is among the group of 24 clinical academics, Coatsworth has made few friends in OzSage, which he believes is a collection of scientists at one extreme of the risk spectrum.He publicly said so on September 13 after OzSage called for Australia to change course on reopening, citing modelling that showed NSW intensive care capacity would be overwhelmed for a month over the Christmas period.That forecast came when the 7-day average daily case load in NSW was 1400 but the model was based on there being daily cases of more than 2000 when it reopened.

The 7-day average has since fallen to just above 900 and NSW will reopen within a fortnight when 70 per cent of eligible adults are fully vaccinated.The ANU, whose Latin motto, Naturam Primum Cognoscere Rerum, means: "First to learn the nature of things.

"Well, we are certainly learning a lot about the nature of things!Josh Frydenberg,celebrity TreasurerPerhaps the most disturbing thing about Josh Frydenberg launching his own regular podcast is that it's not very surprising.All you need to know about this dubious enterprise is that he's partnering with someone renowned for their work with frat house comedy duo Hamish and Andy and that the Treasurer of Australia isn't the slightest bit embarrassed by this perfect match.The momentous news came yesterday, the day he announced the final budget outcome for financial 2021 (a $134 billion deficit to add to the Commonwealth debt pile) and that the Morrison government would shortly cease funding the COVID-19 disaster payment just as Victoria's daily infection numbers exploded by 50 per cent.Frydenberg's lust for meaningless exposure is insatiable.

There is almost no occurrence or development too banal to force upon every single person in his WhatsApp contacts.Turn the dial to FM on any given morning and he's regaling Dirtbag and Nongface with the tedious particulars of what he microwaved for dinner the previous evening.
He's been a cabinet minister for six years now, and deputy leader for three.
Why does he still crave this lightweight celebrity nonsense?We'll say it again.
The Treasurer wishes to be taken as a person of substance yet seems incapable of behaving like one.Frydenberg is the hardest worker in Australian politics by a very long way.

If he took even one-quarter of the time he now devotes to writing sophomoric op-eds or devising his next Instagram opportunity and instead spent it deeply engaged in the policy process, ours would surely be the best-run economy in the OECD.We're not holding our breath.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: The campaign to cancel Nick CoatsworthThere are as many opinions as there are experts, said Franklin Delano Roosevelt. And while the COVID-19 pandemic may yet pale in historical comparison to FDR's battle against the Great Depression and World War II, today's crisis has been marked by sharp combat between competing academics.OzSage is a newly established group of public health academics based on the UK's Independent Scientific Advisory Group for Emergencies. According to its website, OzSage met for the first time on August 16.This timing exculpates OzSage, and its members, of any responsibility for a joint complaint signed by 24 clinical academics in early August to the Australian National University against ANU employee, Associate Professor Nick Coatsworth.Coatsworth, better known for his former role as Australia's deputy chief medical officer, was also the subject of a separate but nearly simultaneous complaint signed by, you guessed it, 24 clinical academics and sent to the Royal Australasian College of Physicians.The trigger for the complaints, it seems, was first a May 15 op-ed the handsome doctor wrote for The Sydney Morning Herald discussing his first-hand experience of ensuring effective health advice was disseminated through the media along with his distaste for experts who talked down the safe and effective AstraZeneca vaccine.These gruesome thought crimes were repeated by Coatsworth in another op-ed for our sister publication on July 23.You might think he was onto something here, given the significant rump of Australians too hesitant to take the freely available AstraZeneca due to scaremongering about ultra-rare side effects, which studies continue to show are basically on-par with the risks inherent in the Pfizer jab (whose protections astoundingly wear off quicker than AstraZeneca).ANU's Dean of the College Health and Medicine, Russell Gruen, believed Coatsworth's commentary, should it be perceived as discourteous by other experts, could have potentially breached ANU's code of conduct. He's been a cabinet minister for six years now, and deputy leader for three. Why does he still crave this lightweight celebrity nonsense?We'll say it again. The Treasurer wishes to be taken as a person of substance yet seems incapable of behaving like one.Frydenberg is the hardest worker in Australian politics by a very long way. If he took even one-quarter of the time he now devotes to writing sophomoric op-eds or devising his next Instagram opportunity and instead spent it deeply engaged in the policy process, ours would surely be the best-run economy in the OECD.We're not holding our breath.
